The following is an example of a good response to the case study. 

Introduction and background
This briefing note summarises the main remaining issues in the preparation of our draft proposal for the revised animal welfare regulation. Following the impact assessment concluded last year, a legislative proposal has been prepared and the inter-service consultation was recently concluded. We received positive opinions except for one negative opinion from DG AGRI, setting a condition regarding the preferred option for banning cages for laying hens.

Main issues
The legislative proposal includes new or stricter rules in four areas: 
restricting the use of cages/crates;
ending the killing of day-old male chickens;
banning painful and unnecessary mutilations; and
setting animal welfare requirements at import.

The legislative proposal is based on the medium or high ambition option for all these measures. The cost-benefit analysis from the impact assessment showed that this would be the most efficient way forward. It is also in line with the outcomes of our stakeholder consultations and pressure from citizens. 

Other DGs support our draft proposal except when it comes to the ban on cages for laying hens. DG AGRI are concerned about the risk of unfair competition and raised food prices as a result of a cage ban. They therefore issued a negative opinion in the inter-service consultation. DG AGRI wants to see the low-ambition option (phase-in of a cage ban over 12 years) or even no legislative change at all, whereas the DG SANTE preferred option is the high-ambition option with phase-in over 5 years and no exceptions made. We would also like to see the ban combined with space requirements to ensure that free-range hens have sufficient living area. Sufficient space per animal is also needed for health and safety reasons including to minimise the risk of antimicrobial resistance.

It is true that this high-ambition option would have an impact on food pricing, though our impact assessment shows a lower price impact than what DG AGRI claims. The main limitation is that poultry farmers will be able to house fewer birds per square meter. To some extent, farmers could be compensated for this via the Common Agricultural Policy or other economic incentives.

For small farmers, this seems not to be a main issue, as cage rearing is mostly done by large-scale industrial farms. In several Member States, the cage ban will also make no difference as they already adopted a ban within their national legislation. For internal market purposes, a cage ban would therefore help create a more level playing field.

A more important problem is the competition with imported goods from third countries. This seems to be the real core concern of DG AGRI. Among our proposed options, we did propose to require stricter animal welfare rules also for imported animals and animal products, though our impact assessment implied that the medium ambition option would be the most cost-efficient choice.

Options for the way forward
There seems to be two main options for the way forward: compromise on the cage ban or compromise on the import rules.

A compromise on the cage ban for laying hens would mean abandonning our preferred option to settle at the low or medium options instead. This would still be an improvement compared to the current situation. However, it is likely that the Commission would then be heavily criticised by NGOs as well as by the European Parliament who called for a total ban in shorter time. 

The other possibility would be to focus instead on the real underlying problem raised by DG AGRI: the risk of unfair competition from third countries. DG AGRI have indicated that the transition time and exceptions for small farms are not the real problem, so a compromise solution on the cage ban proposal is not necessarily in their best interest. We could instead try to convince them to change their current position and accept the high-ambition proposal on laying hen cages, in exchange for instead increasing the level of ambition in terms of the export rules (full alignment with EU rules also for third countries).

This would however require another round of talks also with DG TRADE who gave a positive opinion in the inter-service consultation. We have no information about their willingness to agree to such a compromise.

Conclusion
Our recommendation is to, as a first priority, seek a compromise with DG AGRI based on stricter import rules. This would address their main concern while not compromising our preferred options or lowering the level of ambition for animal welfare.

If this fails, the fallback option could be to strike a compromise based on a longer phase-in period of the cage ban (low or medium ambition option).

If you agree to this plan of action, we can start informally consulting DG AGRI and DG TRADE immediately

Headline: The Rise of Driverless Cars

Summary: 

Driverless cars, also known as autonomous vehicles, are a rapidly emerging technology that has the potential to revolutionize the transportation industry. This briefing note provides an overview of driverless cars, their benefits, challenges, and the current state of development.

1. Introduction to Driverless Cars:
   - Driverless cars are vehicles that can operate without human intervention, using a combination of sensors, cameras, and artificial intelligence.
   - They have the potential to improve road safety, reduce traffic congestion, and provide increased mobility for individuals who are unable to drive.

2. Benefits of Driverless Cars:
   - Improved road safety: Driverless cars have the potential to significantly reduce accidents caused by human error.
   - Increased efficiency: Autonomous vehicles can optimize traffic flow, reducing congestion and travel times.
   - Accessibility: Driverless cars can provide transportation options for individuals who are unable to drive, such as the elderly or disabled.
   - Environmental impact: Autonomous vehicles have the potential to reduce emissions and contribute to a more sustainable transportation system.

3. Challenges and Concerns:
   - Legal and regulatory issues: The development and deployment of driverless cars raise questions about liability, insurance, and compliance with existing traffic laws.
   - Ethical considerations: Autonomous vehicles must be programmed to make decisions in potentially life-threatening situations, raising ethical dilemmas.
   - Cybersecurity risks: The reliance on technology and connectivity exposes driverless cars to potential hacking and cyber-attacks.

4. Current State of Development:
   - Several companies, including Tesla, Google, and Uber, are actively developing and testing driverless car technology.
   - Autonomous vehicles are already being used in limited capacities, such as ride-sharing services and delivery vehicles.
   - However, widespread adoption of driverless cars is still several years away, as technological, regulatory, and societal challenges need to be addressed.

In conclusion, driverless cars have the potential to transform the way we travel, offering numerous benefits in terms of safety, efficiency, and accessibility. However, there are also challenges and concerns that need to be addressed before widespread adoption can occur. The development and deployment of driverless cars require careful consideration of legal, ethical, and cybersecurity issues.

The legislative proposal includes new or stricter rules in four areas: 
restricting the use of cages/crates;
ending the killing of day-old male chickens;
banning painful and unnecessary mutilations; and
setting animal welfare requirements at import.

The legislative proposal is based on the medium or high ambition option for all these measures. DG AGRI wants to see the low-ambition option (phase-in of a cage ban over 12 years) or even no legislative change at all, whereas the DG SANTE preferred option is the high-ambition option with phase-in over 5 years and no exceptions made. We would also like to see the ban combined with space requirements to ensure that free-range hens have sufficient living area. Sufficient space per animal is also needed for health and safety reasons including to minimise the risk of antimicrobial resistance.

It is true that this high-ambition option would have an impact on food pricing, though our impact assessment shows a lower price impact than what DG AGRI claims. The main limitation is that poultry farmers will be able to house fewer birds per square meter. To some extent, farmers could be compensated for this via the Common Agricultural Policy or other economic incentives.

For small farmers, this seems not to be a main issue, as cage rearing is mostly done by large-scale industrial farms. In several Member States, the cage ban will also make no difference as they already adopted a ban within their national legislation. For internal market purposes, a cage ban would therefore help create a more level playing field.

A more important problem is the competition with imported goods from third countries. This seems to be the real core concern of DG AGRI. Options for the way forward
There seems to be two main options for the way forward: compromise on the cage ban or compromise on the import rules.

A compromise on the cage ban for laying hens would mean abandonning our preferred option to settle at the low or medium options instead. This would still be an improvement compared to the current situation. However, it is likely that the Commission would then be heavily criticised by NGOs as well as by the European Parliament who called for a total ban in shorter time.

This would however require another round of talks also with DG TRADE who gave a positive opinion in the inter-service consultation. We have no information about their willingness to agree to such a compromise.

Conclusion
Our recommendation is to, as a first priority, seek a compromise with DG AGRI based on stricter import rules. This would address their main concern while not compromising our preferred options or lowering the level of ambition for animal welfare.

If this fails, the fallback option could be to strike a compromise based on a longer phase-in period of the cage ban (low or medium ambition option).

restricting the use of cages/crates;
ending the killing of day-old male chickens;
banning painful and unnecessary mutilations; and
setting animal welfare requirements at import.

A more important problem is the competition with imported goods from third countries. This seems to be the real core concern of DG AGRI. 1. Opportunities and threats of unmanned or remotely piloted vehicles in the European Airspace
1.1. Opportunities of unmanned or remotely piloted vehicles in the European Airspace
- Employement and growth:

Briefing Note / DG Mobility and Transport
Automated vehicle technologies allow the transfer of driving functions from a human driver to a computer. Automation, and in particular digitalisation, of driving will change road transport in a way which is viewed as a revolution in the field of mobility. However,automated vehicle technologies require an effective legislative framework that can foster European leadership and competitiveness, while addressing a number of legitimate concerns.
Potentials and challenges of vehicle automation
Potential benefits of vehicle automation
1. Increased road safety: As human error is the main reason for road traffic accidents, driving which is automatically controlled by a computer is expected to make future road transport safer and more secure for drivers and pedestrians alike. A KPMG report predicts an 80% drop in accidents in 20 years.
2. Environmental benefits: Vehicles will be lighter and more fuel efficient which will lead to reduced energy demand. In addition, their used is optimised and they pick up and drop customers constantly without needing to spend energy and time looking for parking (i.e. in peak hours, these vehicles will be used 90% of the time in large cities).
3. Increased affordability of car ownership/sharing: The costs of car ownership are expected to drop by 75%.
4. Accesibility: People with reduced mobility, disability or living in rural areas will have easier access to mobility services.
Challenges and drawbacks
1. Unclear liability in case of accidents: Although reduced, accidents will continue happening and there needs to be a way to ensure that the liabile party is clear and that victims are compensated.
2. Ethical issues: Given the data driven nature of driveless car sharing, some privacy and data safety issues will emerge. The automated systems will also take decisions (e.g. among different options in a car crash scenario) which will need ethical oversight.
3. Job market impacts: The development of the sector might result in the displacement of some jobs and the loss of others. The size of the sector is considerable (e.g. 2% of US total employment).
4. Difficulties adapting to fragmeted road traffic regulation: Europe has different national juristdictions when it comes to road traffic and this can inder the deployment of new technologies for systems or vehicles.
The different levels of automation and their deployment
Levels of Automation
There are different levels of automation ranging from already deployed mechanisms like park assistance or traffic jam assistance to vehicles without a driving wheel.
The US Department of Transportations's National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) an dETRAC provide different definitions of 5 levels of automation. All in all, there are 3 stages whose differences will be determinan for regulation and insurance: Automated, Autonomous and Driveress.
Deployment
The first commercial uses of the technology are likely to be driverless trucks first deployed as part of convoys lead by a driven vehicle and then as fully autonomous series of automated trucks. Motorways will be the safets place for CAD test as they are pedestrian free, often straight and uniform across Europe.
Regulatory and legal frameworks, state of play
The Vienna Convention on Road Traffic from 1968 (ratified by all EU MS except of Spain) is an international treaty designed to facilitate international road traffic and increase road safety by establishing stadard traffic rules among parties. However, Article 8 establishes that the driver is always fully in control and responsible for the behaviour of a vehicle in traffic. Its amendment still demands that each vehicle must have a driver so the Convention needs to be further amended to adapt to driverless vehicles and clarified as different countries are choosing to interpret Article 8 in different ways.
An EU regulation of the sector could mean that the EC sents the standards for the later international UN treaty, which could take up to 5 years to modify.
Technical requirements for Vehicles are harmonised in the framework of two UNECE agreements (1958 and 1998) where the EU is a contracting party. In addition, Certificates of Conformity, issued by any EU member state, certifying that a vehicle meets all relevant legal requirements, are accepted in all other members.
Regulatory standards for robots are being planned in several countries and the EU needs to take the lead on setting the standards to avoid having to follow standards set by others.he regulation of the sector will need to overcome the challenges identified including the harmonization of traffic regulations and vehicle requirements but also data processing, liability issues, infrastructure and vehicle to vehicle (V2V) interoperability.
Ongoing work in the EU
The White Paper on the Furture of Europe identifies autonomous vehicles as an areas where the EU can deliver tangible benefits to citizens.
The Commission foresees to publish a Roadmap as part of the EU Transport Strategy on the 31st of May.
National EU leaders signed an agreement in Rome to allow cross-border tests and experiments with autonomous vehicles and to establish a national contact point to approve them.
Suggestions from the European Parliament to develop EU standards for the sector include:
1. Creating a specific legal status for robots to establish who is liable in case of accidents.
2. Making inusrance mandatory and creating a supplementary fund to ensure that victims of accidents involving driveless cars are compensated
3. Creating a European Agency for robotics and artificial intelligence to support public authorities with technical, ethical and regulatory expertise in the field.
4. The creation of a voluntary ethical code of conduct on robotics for researchers and designers could ensure that they operate in accordance with legal and ethical standards while respecting human dignity.
